title: 108_s976
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jamestown 400th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 2003". Congress recognizes the historical significance of the Jamestown colony, the multicultural society it formed, and the lasting impact of its institutions on the United States. The National Park Service, the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities, and the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation collectively own and operate significant resources related to the early history of Jamestown. In 2000, Congress established the Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission to ensure a suitable national observance of the Jamestown 2007 anniversary and support marketing efforts for a commemorative coin. The commemorative coin will bring national and international attention to the lasting legacy of Jamestown, Virginia, with proceeds assisting in financing related activities. The commemorative coin will help finance a national observance in 2007 of the 400th anniversary of the founding of Jamestown, Virginia. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. $1 silver coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1,500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting coins under this Act from authorized sources. Silver for the coins will be obtained only from established stockpiles under a specific Act. The design of coins is specified in Section 4. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the settlement of Jamestown, Virginia, with inscriptions including the coin's value, the year "2007", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Jamestown 2007 Steering Committee. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the settlement of Jamestown, Virginia and will include inscriptions such as the coin's value, the year "2007", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with various organizations and committees. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins only between January 1, 2007, and December 31, 2007. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount, and bulk sales will also be offered at a reasonable discount. The coins minted under this Act will be sold with a surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin and $10 per coin for the $1 coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary shall distribute surcharges from the sale of coins minted under this Act to recipients listed in paragraphs (2) and (3). 50% of the surcharges go to the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation for programs promoting Jamestown's legacies, while the other 50% is distributed equally among specified entities to sustain the mission of preserving Jamestown. Entities specified under this subparagraph include the Secretary of the Department of the Interior, the President of the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities, and the Chairman of the Jamestown Yorktown Foundation. They are tasked with preserving Jamestown, enhancing educational programs, improving infrastructure and research activities, and supporting the commemoration of the 400th anniversary of Jamestown. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the entities specified in subsection (a) of the Yorktown Foundation to examine their books, records, and data related to the expenditure of distributed amounts. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is in place.
